title: Permanent bans
body: Alright so lets start this off by me saying I am scum, I ruined many games and have been banned d around 3 times before I got my finally permanent ban, did I deserve it? Hell fucking yes I did. Before we start let me say I am sorry to everyone's game I was ruined everyone's day I have ruined and even worse to everyone that I have ever flamed. I know u probably don't even remember me but I'm sorry, when I was younger I was rude had anger management issues and was extremely explosive, this resulted in the perma ban of my account of 3 years with over 15,000 hours played and around 600 or more dollars sunk into it. When I was permanent banned I was devestated and I turned my self around, I went to anger manament classes as well as read many books on anger management and haven't even touched the game in awhile. I spent a long time playing rugby focusing on school and learning to control that rage that's built up inside of me due to family issues with my father being a drug addicted and brother following his footsteps. After a year of training I feel like I have learned to control my anger and even learned how to diffuse arguments with my self as well as with others. I've learned a lot of self control. Now I figured I was ready to come back as a reformed player and benefit the community and game that I once terriozied only to find out that perma bans are 100% indefinite and the experiment to allow players to reform was destroyed by people like the old me. So my question to you as the community that I once flamed but still loved, to the game that I once ruined but still was addicted to, do you think there should be a system in league where after a year or more u can come back and get your permanently  banned account resolved if you pass a certain reform sheet or maybe even something like where the next ban with negative activity results in an immediate perma ban as if your name is on a black list or something that can never be wiped? I feel like I deserve another chance but Maybe I'm wrong maybe I'm still scum but I think they should give players like me a chance to reform and be an asset to the community instead of someone who wants to hurt it thank you for your time have a great day

replies.body: I do agree there could be some slight changes to the punishment tiers, but not revoking a permanent ban. Riot had a program for this and it failed horribly, as 95% of the players went right back to their toxic behavior. I'm glad you were able to turn around and become a better person through this, but you're a rarity. You may not be able to get your account back, but I encourage you to stick around and share your experiences with others on the PB board so maybe others can learn from it.

> as 95% of the players went right back to their toxic behavior.

So Riots punishment is 5% effective. Only 5% of punished players reformed.

? No. This was for removing permanent bans, meaning that 95% of the time it was the correct decision, and trying to reform them after that point is a futile effort. The higher tier penalty a player receives the less likely they are to change; most players that receive a chat restriction immediately improve and never need another.

Permanent ban is the punishment I was talking about. 5% of permanently banned players reformed. Permanent banning is 5% effective. 

Chat restriction is an alternate punishment. It sounds like it is more effective than permanent bans.

Hopefully, that clears things up. It should reconfirm that permanent bans are not good reformation tools.

The intention of a perma isn't to reform, it's to get them out of the community because they've proven they have no intention of doing so. It *can* reform people, but that's not the primary purpose.

It's the "Level 20 Challenge" program that removed those permabans that was only 5% effective, and why they do not remove permas like that anymore.

1. Riot employees are on record telling people to create a new account after being permanently banned. It's a pretty ass hole move to encourage someone who has "proven no intention of reform", to reenter the community on a smurf account.
2. Riot has "unjustly" permanently banned accounts before. Why would Riot want to intentionally ban an innocent player? I'm guessing they unintentionally banned accounts.

The point of a permanent ban is that it is permanent.

If there was a system to retrieve a permanent banned account, it would be gamed. Riot gives you the chance to start fresh, on a new account, with no prior punishment history. That's more than many games do.

If permanent bans were made less permanent, it would remove the incentive to reform like you truly did for most people. People would just wait the time then game whatever test, come back not having truly reformed. And they'd go right back to their old attitude and behavior because they haven't reformed.

But u see that's fixable as their name could be on all. Black list like said in the comment where they would only need one reasonable report to be sent back and who's gonna wait a year to play on their main those true toxic players will most likely just start a new account and in a year be in the same place where as truly reformed players would have s chance to redeem them selfs

If you spent 500+ dollars on your main, wouldn't you want to go back to it? 

One game is still 9 other people being games ruined that could've been prevented by not permitting them back.

The bottom line is OP acknowledges this was tried before and was a huge resounding failure. Yet OP does not acknowledge that sometimes in life innocent people get caught in the system for the greater good.

It's a balance between false positives and false negatives. Riot has decided, rightfully so in my opinion, that having false positives (where people are permabanned without recourse when they may have reformed) is better than the alternative of false negatives (letting very likely nonreformed players back in the game because they pass an arbitrary test).

Sadly OP has realized that permanent in life usually means permanent. Indefinite means there could be recourse. Permanent means permanent.
